<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 356, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Pure Mathematics 3 (P3)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 455, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 352, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 368, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 326, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 448, 284, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 590, 510]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 606, 526]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 556]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 572, 440, 588]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 101, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 625, 92]]<|/det|>
Given that \(2\ln (x + 4) - \ln x = \ln (x + a)\), express \(x\) in terms of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 129, 97, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 524, 160]]<|/det|>
Use the substitution \(u = 3x + 1\) to find \(\int \frac{3x}{3x + 1} \mathrm{~d}x.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 129, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 188, 97, 207]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 188, 390, 207]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\operatorname {f}(x)\) is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[395, 214, 601, 234]]<|/det|>
\[\operatorname {f}(x) = x^{3} + a x^{2} - a x + 14,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 241, 620, 261]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) is a constant. It is given that \((x + 2)\) is a factor of \(\operatorname {f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 272, 153, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 272, 316, 291]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 304, 153, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 303, 779, 322]]<|/det|>
Show that, when \(a\) has this value, the equation \(\operatorname {f}(x) = 0\) has only one real root.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 304, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 350, 96, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 350, 828, 369]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(3\mathrm{e}^{2x}\mathrm{y} + \mathrm{e}^{x}\mathrm{y}^{3} = 14\). Find the gradient of the curve at the point (0, 2).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 351, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 402, 96, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 396, 620, 432]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\int_{0}^{p}4\mathrm{e}^{-\frac{1}{2}x}\mathrm{d}x = 9\), where \(p\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 445, 156, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 444, 400, 477]]<|/det|>
Show that \(p = 2\ln \left(\frac{8p + 16}{7}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 450, 920, 470]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 488, 153, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 488, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
Use an iterative process based on the equation in part **(i)** to find the value of \(p\) correct to 3 significant figures. Use a starting value of 3.5 and give the result of each iteration to 5 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 520, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 565, 96, 584]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 565, 623, 584]]<|/det|>
Two planes have equations \(3x - y + 2z = 9\) and \(x + y - 4z = -1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 597, 156, 615]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 597, 484, 615]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between the planes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 597, 920, 615]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 628, 153, 645]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 626, 655, 645]]<|/det|>
Find a vector equation of the line of intersection of the planes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 628, 920, 645]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 673, 96, 692]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 673, 153, 692]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 673, 732, 692]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\sec \theta + 2 \cosec \theta = 3 \cosec 2 \theta\), show that \(2 \sin \theta + 4 \cos \theta = 3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 673, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 705, 153, 723]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 704, 920, 739]]<|/det|>
Express \(2 \sin \theta + 4 \cos \theta\) in the form \(R \sin (\theta + \alpha)\) where \(R > 0\) and \(0^{\circ} < \alpha < 90^{\circ}\), giving the value of \(\alpha\) correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 720, 920, 739]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 752, 151, 769]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 750, 747, 769]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(\sec \theta + 2 \sec \theta = 3 \sec \theta 2 \theta\) for \(0^{\circ} < \theta < 360^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 752, 920, 769]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 807, 96, 826]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 802, 153, 821]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 802, 520, 836]]<|/det|>
Express \(\frac{7x^{2} + 8}{(1 + x)^{2}(2 - 3x)}\) in partial fractions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 806, 920, 826]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 857, 153, 875]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 850, 918, 892]]<|/det|>
Hence expand \(\frac{7x^{2} + 8}{(1 + x)^{2}(2 - 3x)}\) in ascending powers of \(x\) up to and including the term in \(x^{2}\), simplifying the coefficients.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 884, 920, 902]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 885, 92]]<|/det|>
Without using a calculator, use the formula for the solution of a quadratic equation to solve

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 100, 599, 120]]<|/det|>
\[(2 - \mathrm{i})z^{2} + 2z + 2 + \mathrm{i} = 0.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 127, 460, 145]]<|/det|>
Give your answers in the form \(a + bi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 127, 918, 145]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 146, 181]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 161, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
The complex number \(w\) is defined by \(w = 2\mathrm{e}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi \mathrm{i}}\). In an Argand diagram, the points \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\) represent the complex numbers \(w\), \(w^{3}\) and \(w^{*}\) respectively (where \(w^{*}\) denotes the complex conjugate of \(w\)). Draw the Argand diagram showing the points \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\), and calculate the area of triangle \(ABC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 212, 918, 230]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 256, 104, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 262, 682, 495]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 515, 504, 534]]<|/det|>
A particular solution of the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 543, 598, 573]]<|/det|>
\[3y^{2}\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = 4(y^{3} + 1)\cos^{2}x\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 579, 920, 629]]<|/det|>
is such that \(y = 2\) when \(x = 0\). The diagram shows a sketch of the graph of this solution for \(0\leqslant x\leqslant 2\pi\); the graph has stationary points at \(A\) and \(B\). Find the \(y\)-coordinates of \(A\) and \(B\), giving each coordinate correct to 1 decimal place.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 613, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 75, 564, 90]]<|/det|>
# BLANK PAGE
